para.paratext: Reason dictates that “a stay of creditors from collecting their claims against the debtor and his property from and after the filing of a petition under the Bankruptcy Act is indispensable to bankruptcy administration.”[1] Congress has explained this need for an automatic stay as follows:

The automatic stay is one of the fundamental debtor protections provided bankruptcy laws. It gives the debtor a breathing spell from his creditors. It stops all collection effort, all harassment, and all foreclosure actions. It permits the debtor to attempt a repayment or reorganization plan, or simply to be relieved of the financial pressure that drove him into bankruptcy.

The automatic stay also provides creditor protection. Without it, certain creditors would be able to pursue their own remedies against debtor's property. Those who acted first would obtain payment of claims in preference to and to the detriment of other creditors. Bankruptcy is designed to provide an orderly liquidation procedure under which all creditors are treated equally. A race of diligence by creditors for the debtor's assets prevents that.[2]
Indeed, absent some means for staying the continued pursuit of nonbankruptcy remedies, effective access to relief under the Bankruptcy Code depends entirely on the unanimous support of creditors.

Recognizing both the unlikelihood of such uniform creditor acquiescence and the instinctively nonutilitarian nature of marketplace realities, the Bankruptcy Code section 362 provides for an automatic stay upon adverse creditor action.[3] By necessity, the “scope of [section 362's provisions in this respect are] broad, but they do not apply automatically to non-debtor entities.[4] [Indeed,] all proceedings are stayed, including arbitration, license revocation, administrative, and judicial proceedings.”[5] Logically, this protection extends to nonbankruptcy litigation against the debtor,[6] as well as any related appeals[7] or processes.[8] Still further, as a consequence of section 362's mandate, the Bankruptcy Code also effects a stay upon acts of collection, lien enforcement,[9] and other judicial or nonjudicial actions which might constitute an attempt to enforce or collect upon a prepetition claim.[10] Also Also stayed are a wide range of actions which might interfere with property of the estate, the debtor, or the integrity of the bankruptcy proceedings.[11]

Actions taken in violation of the Code's automatic stay provisions are void ab initio or voidable, and without legal effect.[12] Furthermore, it should be noted that parties willfully violating the automatic stay may find themselves subject to compensatory and punitive damages.[13] For a violation of the automatic stay to be “willful” within the meaning of section 362(k), the court must only find that the actor intended its actions and had notice of the existence of the automatic stay.[14] Once the willfulness of the violation has been established, an “individual” injured by the violation must be awarded reasonable and necessary attorneys fees and compensatory damages.[15] The court has discretion as to whether to award punitive damages, and most courts require a showing of egregious conduct before doing so.[16] Note that an action for damages for violating the automatic stay survives the dismissal of the bankruptcy case and the bankruptcy court will retain jurisdiction to hear and determine the matter.[17]

At the same time, despite its breadth and the severity of its consequence, it must be observed that the scope of bankruptcy's automatic stay does have certain limitations.[18] In particular, the stay does not operate to enjoin or prohibit the following actions:
Commencement or continuation of a criminal proceeding;[19]
Establishing paternity, establishing or modifying an order for alimony, maintenance, or support, as well as collecting of alimony, maintenance, or support from nonestate property;[20]
Action to perfect or maintain perfection of an interest permitted under 11 U.S.C.A. § 546(b);[2121]
Commencement or continuation of an action by a governmental unit to enforce its police or regulatory powers;[22]
An action to offset or net out a mutual debt and claim concerning commodities or securities contracts;[23]
Setoff of any mutual debt and claim under or in connection with a repurchase agreement that involves a claim against the debtor for a margin payment or settlement payment;[24]

Commencement of an action by the Department of Housing and Urban Development to foreclose a mortgage or deed of trust which is insured under the National Housing Act and which encumbers property consisting of five or more living units;[25]
Issuance to the debtor by a government unit of a notice of tax deficiency, an audit or assessment to determine tax liability, or a demand for tax returns;[2626]
Actions by the lessor of nonresidential real property to obtain possession of such property, where the lease terminated by its own terms;[27]
Presentment of a negotiable instrument and issuance of any notice of dishonor;[28]

From and after 90 days after the filing of a Chapter 11 petition, the commencement or continuation of an action by the Secretary of Transportation or the Secretary of Commerce to foreclose a preferred ship or fleet mortgage;[29]
Any action regarding the accreditation or licensing of the debtor as an educational institution;[30]
Any action by the Secretary of Education regarding the eligibility of the debtor to participate in programs authorized under the Higher Education Act of 1965;[31]
Setoff of any mutual debt in connection with a swap agreement;[32]
Creation or perfection of a statutory lien for ad valorum taxes by a political subdivision of a State or by the District of Columbia.[33]
Certain acts to withhold funds for the benefit of pension, profit-sharing, stock bonus, or other qualified plans.[34]
Acts to enforce a lien or security interest as to which stay relief has previously been granted on the basis of an abusive bankruptcy filing.[35]

Certain acts to evict an individual debtor under a lease of residential property whereby judgment was rendered prior to bankruptcy, or in instances of illegal activity or imminent threat to property.[36]
Any transfer that is not avoidable under section 544 and that is not avoidable under section 549.[3737]
Certain actions by securities self-regulatory bodies.[38]
Setoff of income tax refunds by governmental units.[39]
Exercise of certain rights under master netting agreements.[40]
Exclusion of the debtor from Medicare or any other federal health care program by the Secretary of Health and Human Services.[41]
Thus, broad as its terms may seem as an initial matter, the automatic stay has definite parameters of application, and its terms come subject to many limitations.

When applicable, the stay of section 362 continues until the case is closed or dismissed, a discharge is granted or denied, or the property in question is no longer part of the estate.[42] A party in interest may move the court for relief from the stay (terminating, annulling, modifying, or conditioning the stay) under the following grounds:
for cause,[43] which may include the fact that the case was filed in bad faith[44] or the lack of adequate protection;[45]
because debtor does not have equity in the property in question,[46] and such property is not necessary for an effective reorganization;[47]
in a single asset real estate case,[48] the debtor has not either filed a confirmable plan or commenced mandatory payments to the associated secured creditor;[49] or
the case involves a scheme to hinder, delay or defraud creditors with regard to real property.[50]

Importantly, the Bankruptcy Rules do not require parties desiring relief from the automatic stay to institute an adversary proceeding as a condition to obtaining such relief. Rather, in lieu of commencing a full-scale civil action in the bankruptcy court, Importantly, the Bankruptcy Rules do not require parties desiring relief from the automatic stay to institute an adversary proceeding as a condition to obtaining such relief. Rather, in lieu of commencing a full-scale civil action in the bankruptcy court, Rule 4001 provides that a request for relief may be made by motion,[51] and if irreparable injury is imminent, relief can be granted on an ex parte basis.[52]

The Practitioner also should note a uniform consistency between the provisions for an automatic stay in section 362, the provisions for the use, sale, and lease of property contained in section 363, and the rules for adequate protection contained in section 361. Section 363(c)(1) provides that if the debtor in possession or trustee operates the debtor's business, the debtor or the trustee is allowed to utilize the property of the estate in the ordinary course of business.[53] Nonetheless, if the utilization of the debtor's assets jeopardizes other parties in interest, they may move the court to restrict or prohibit the use, sale, or lease of property by the debtor in possession or trustee unless adequate protection is furnished pursuant to section 361.[54] Likewise, a party in interest may move the court for relief from the stay for cause, including the lack of adequate protection as defined by section 361.[55] As they bear upon section 362's application, these provisions simply mean that the automatic stay is not set in stone, and it may be dissolved or modified at the request of creditors and parties in interest.[56]

Lastly, it must be understood that, while stays of action outside the bankruptcy forum begin with an application of section 362, the power of the court to enjoin actions for the benefit of the estate does not end with that provision. As the legislative history itself suggests:

The court has ample other powers to stay actions not covered by the automatic stay. Section 105, of proposed title II, derived from Bankruptcy Act section 2a(15), grants the power to issue orders necessary or appropriate to carry out the provisions of title II. The bankruptcy courts are brought within the scope of the All Writs Statute, 28 U.S.C. 1651 (1970), and are given the powers of a court of law, equity, and admiralty. … Stays or injunctions issued under these sections will not be automatic upon the commencement of the case, but will be granted or issued under the usual rules for the issuances of injunctions. By excepting an act or action from the automatic stay, the bill simply requires the trustee to move the court into action, rather than requiring the stayed party to request relief from the stay. There are some actions, enumerated in the exceptions, that generally should not be stayed automatically upon the commencement of the case, for reasons of either policy or practicality. Thus, the court will have to determine on a case-by-case basis whether a particular action which may be harmful to the estate should be stayed.[57]

These supplemental powers under Bankruptcy Code section 105 provide yet another means of reaching the automatic stay's twin goals: (1) to envelope the debtor's assets and operations within the protection of the bankruptcy court, and (2) to funnel all litigation concerning the debtor and the property of the estate into that same forum.
Code section 362 provides:

(a) Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a petition filed under section 301, 302, or 303 of this title, or an application filed under section 5(a)(3) of the Securities Investor Protection Act of 1970, operates as a stay, applicable to all entities, of—

the commencement or continuation, including the issuance or employment of process, of a judicial, administrative, or other action or proceeding against the debtor that was or could have been commenced before the commencement of the case under this title, or to recover a claim against the debtor that arose before the commencement of the case under this title;
the enforcement, against the debtor or against property of the estate, of a judgment obtained before the commencement of the case under this title;
any act to obtain possession of property of the estate or of property from the estate or to exercise control over property of the estate;
any act to create, perfect, or enforce any lien against property of the estate;
any act to create, perfect, or enforce against property of the debtor any lien to the extent that such lien secures a claim that arose before the commencement of the case under this title;
any act to collect, assess, or recover a claim against the debtor that arose before the commencement of the case under this title;
the setoff of any debt owing to the debtor that arose before the commencement of the case under this title against any claim against the debtor; and

the commencement or continuation of a proceeding before the United States Tax Court concerning a corporate debtor's tax liability for a taxable period the bankruptcy court may determine or concerning the tax liability of a debtor who is an individual for a taxable period ending before the date of the order for relief under this title.
(c) Except as provided in subsections (d), (e), (f), and (h) of this section—
the stay of an act against property of the estate under subsection (a) of this section continues until such property is no longer property of the estate;
the stay of any other act under subsection (a) of this section continues until the earliest of—
the time the case is closed;
the time the case is dismissed; or
if the case is a case under chapter 7 of this title concerning an individual or a case under chapter 9, 11, 12, or 13 of this title, the time a discharge is granted or denied;

(k)(1) Except as provided in paragraph (2), an individual injured by any willful violation of a stay provided by this section shall recover actual damages, including costs and attorneys' fees, and, in appropriate circumstances, may recover punitive damages.

(2) If such violation is based on an action taken by an entity in the good faith belief that subsection (h) applies to the debtor, the recovery under paragraph (1) of this subsection against such entity shall be limited to actual damages.

11 U.S.C.A. § 362. The automatic stay arises upon the filing of the petition and cannot be imposed retroactively. See In re Buckskin Realty, Inc., 525 B.R. 4 (Bankr. E.D.N.Y. 2015) (declining to rule that bankruptcy petition was filed before a foreclosure sale; court could not grant nunc pro tunc relief, and the excusable neglect standard of Rule 9006 was inapplicable to the filing of a petition).

See, e.g., McCartney v. Integra Nat. Bank North, 106 F.3d 506, 509–510, 37 Collier Bankr. Cas. 2d (MB) 713, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) P 77290 (3d Cir. 1997) (“[I]t is universally acknowledged that an automatic stay of proceedings accorded by § 362 may not be invoked by entities such as sureties, guarantors, co-obligors, or others with a similar legal or factual nexus to the debtor.”); In re Uni-Marts, LLC, 399 B.R. 400, 415 (Bankr. D. Del. 2009) (“In general, only the debtor is afforded the protections of the automatic stay under section 362; conversely, third-parties do not receive the protection of the automatic stay”); In re Hart, 530 B.R. 293, 303 (Bankr. E.D. Pa. 2015) (debtor must have filed an adversary proceeding to extend the stay to cover a related non-debtor entity). The court may extend the stay to cover non-debtor entities in an unusual situation, such as “when there is such identity between the debtor and the third-party defendant that the debtor may be said to be the real party defendant and that a judgment against the third-party defendant will in effect be a judgment or finding against the debtor.” A.H. Robins Co., Inc. v. Piccinin, 788 F.2d 994, 999, 14 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 752, 15 Collier Bankr. Cas. 2d (MB) 235, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) P 71094 (4th Cir. 1986) (rejected by, Algemene Bank Nederland, N.V. v. Hallwood Industries, Inc., 133 B.R. 176 (W.D. Pa. 1991)) and (rejected by, In re PTI Holding Corp., 346 B.R. 820 (Bankr. D. Nev. 2006)); see also In re FPSDA I, LLC, 2012 WL 6681794, *8 (Bankr. E.D. N.Y. 2012), as corrected, (Dec. 26, 2012) and appeal dismissed, 2014 WL 108419 (E.D. N.Y. 2014) (“Ultimately, the automatic stay may only be extended to protect non-debtors where such relief is ‘necessary to protect the debtor’s reorganization,' and where the lawsuit sought to be stayed is ‘sufficiently likely to have a material effect upon … reorganization efforts.’”); In re Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC, 423 B.R. 98 (E.D. Pa. 2010).
H.R. Rep. No. 95-595, at 340 (1977). As one group of commentators has explained,

The Bankruptcy Code freezes the status quo at the outset of the bankruptcy proceeding. This “automatic stay” amounts “to an ex parte temporary restraining order against the world without the need to show irreparable injury or other requisites necessary for preliminary injunctive relief.” It is one of the fundamental debtor protections provided by the bankruptcy laws [and it] gives the debtor a breathing spell from his creditors. It stops all collection efforts, all harassment, and all foreclosure actions [and] permits the debtor to attempt a repayment or reorganization plan, or simply to be released of the financial pressures that drove him into bankruptcy…. The stay arises in all bankruptcy cases triggered by the filing of a bankruptcy petition [, and it] protects both creditors and the debtor. From a creditor's perspective, the stay “prevent[s] creditors from trying to steal a march on each other.” From the debtor's perspective, the stay protects its assets by providing temporary relief from creditors. For creditors, the stay not only forestalls “the race to the courthouse” but also the dismemberment of the estate by creditors seeking to gain unfair advantage.

Maizel & Whitaker, The Government's Contractual Rights and Bankruptcy's Automatic Stay, 752 PLI/Comm 603, 607 (1997) (citations omitted). but see In re Holyoke Nursing Home Inc., 273 B.R. 305, 38 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 250, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) ¶ 78578 (Bankr. D. Mass. 2002), subsequently aff'd, 372 F.3d 1, 43 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 34, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) P 80110 (1st Cir. 2004) (payments made prepetition to the debtor-provider pursuant to its provider agreement under the Medicare program and amounts owing to the debtor as a result of its services rendered postpetition arose from the “same transaction” so that the recoupment doctrine (as opposed to the setoff doctrine) applied. It followed that the automatic stay did not prevent recoupment of prepetition overpayments out of amounts owing to the debtor for postpetition services).

Section 362(a)(1) precludes “the … continuation … of a judicial, administrative or other proceeding against the debtor that was or could have been commenced before the commencement of the case.” 11 U.S.C.A. § 362(a)(1). Thus, as a necessary part of its functioning, the automatic stay halts all proceedings against the debtor as of the commencement of the case. See, e.g., Ellis v. Consolidated Diesel Elec. Corp., 894 F.2d 371, 372–73, 20 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 56, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) ¶ 73214 (10th Cir. 1990) (summary judgment rendered two weeks after bankruptcy petition's filing was held invalid; district court lacked power to enter order prior to termination or modification of stay); Ellison v. Northwest Engineering Co., 707 F.2d 1310, 1311, 11 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 401 (11th Cir. 1983) (prior to stay relief, appellate court stayed from handing down decision on case that had been briefed and argued prepetition).

At the same time, the stay only applies to the “continuation of actions against the debtor”; actions against other parties (including appeals brought by the debtor in actions that were originally commenced by the debtor) normally will not be stayed and must go forward unless stayed under the bankruptcy court's section 105 equitably discretionary powers. See, e.g., Agrawal v. Ogden, 753 Fed. Appx. 644 (10th Cir. 2018) (“But § ‘362(a) automatically stays proceedings against the debtor only and not co-debtors.’”); American Prairie Const. Co. v. Hoich, 560 F.3d 780, 51 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 114 (8th Cir. 2009) (automatic stay that arose in bankruptcy case filed by company during pendency of appeal in contractor's breach of contract action against company and investor did not extend to issues raised by investor, as nondebtor codefendant, on appeal); Parker v. Bain, 68 F.3d 1131, 1137–38, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) ¶ 76652 (9th Cir. 1995) (counterclaim defendant/debtor's appeal of summary judgment motion stayed under section 362; plaintiff/debtor's appeal of dismissal of claim not stayed, as it was “a claim by, not against the debtor, and its successful prosecution would ‘inure to the benefit of the bankruptcy estate.’”). Questions also have arisen regarding whether the physical entry or docketing of a judgment or arbitration award rendered before the bankruptcy filing will constitute “the … continuation … of a judicial proceeding” that is subject to § 362(a)(1). The majority of courts facing this question have concluded, however, that “the simple and ‘ministerial’ act of the entry of a judgment by the court clerk does not constitute the continuation of a judicial proceeding under section 362(a)(1).” Rexnord Holdings, Inc. v. Bidermann, 21 F.3d 522 (2d Cir. 1994); In re Knightsbridge Development Co. Inc., 884 F.2d 145, 19 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 1229, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) P 73164 (4th Cir. 1989).

Somewhat contrary to reasonable expectation, whether section 362(a)(1) operates to stay an appeal in prebankruptcy litigation may turn, not so much on which party has initiated the appeal, but instead on the original posture of the parties in the original proceeding. See, e.g., Farley v. Henson, 2 F.3d 273, 275, 24 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 905, 29 Collier Bankr. Cas. 2d (MB) 702, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) ¶ 75389 (8th Cir. 1993) (appeal by defendant/debtor stayed as the “continuation” of a “proceeding against the debtor”); In re Berry Estates, Inc., 812 F.2d 67, 71, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) ¶ 71659 (2d Cir. 1987) (“whether an action is by or against a debtor is determined by the debtor's status at the time the action was begun, not by who was ahead when the bankruptcy petition was filed”). For this reason, when the debtor commences the prepetition litigation, subsequent appeals taken by the debtor should not be stayed. See Carley Capital Group v. Fireman's Fund Ins. Co., 889 F.2d 1126, 1127, 19 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 1754 (D.C. Cir. 1989) (plaintiff/debtor's appeal from judgment entered against it was not stayed; automatic stay “‘by its terms only stays proceedings against the debtor,’ and ‘does not address actions brought by the debtor which would inure to the benefit of the bankruptcy estate.’”) (citations omitted). Conversely, an appeal of an order affirming an arbitration award against a defendant/debtor should be stayed in bankruptcy. See Matter of Arbitration Between Barbier and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., 943 F.2d 249, 250, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) ¶ 74246, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) ¶ 74295 (2d Cir. 1991) (“the filing of the bankruptcy petition … automatically stayed this appeal, since the appeal arises from an action brought to confirm an arbitration award ‘against the debtor’”). Similar rules govern the circumstance of an appeal that is taken from a decision on a counterclaim in prebankruptcy litigation involving the debtor. See, e.g., Koolik v. Markowitz, 40 F.3d 567, 568, 26 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 317, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) ¶ 76202 (2d Cir. 1994) (debtor initiated prepetition action, and a judgment was entered against the debtor on the defendant's counterclaim, leading the debtor to seek postpetition appeal; court held that “a defendant who is awarded judgment on a counterclaim is no less a judgment creditor than is a plaintiff who is awarded judgment on a claim asserted in the complaint,” such that “an answer that asserts a counterclaim against a plaintiff who becomes a bankruptcy debtor is an ‘action or proceeding against the debtor’ within the meaning of 362(a)(1), notwithstanding the fact that the [debtor] initiated the lawsuit”).

In this regard, it should be noted that Bankruptcy Code section 108(c) also tolls an unexpired and otherwise applicable statute of limitations for creditor to commence or continue a civil action on claim against debtor, until 30 days after notice of expiration of automatic stay. See 11 U.S.C.A. § 108(e); see also In re 201 Forest Street, LLC, 422 B.R. 888, 52 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 201, 63 Collier Bankr. Cas. 2d (MB) 781, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) P 81700 (B.A.P. 1st Cir. 2010) (because mortgagee was prohibited by the automatic stay from initiating a civil foreclosure action, the section of the Bankruptcy Code governing extension of time extended the five-year period within which it could commence a civil action to enforce its mortgage, such that the mortgage was not discharged by operation of the state law); In re Shamus Holdings, LLC, 409 B.R. 598 (Bankr. D. Mass. 2009), rev'd on other grounds, 2010 WL 4181137 (D. Mass. 2010), decision aff'd, 642 F.3d 263, 54 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 221 (1st Cir. 2011) (Bankruptcy Code provision extending any applicable nonbankruptcy law period for creditor to commence or continue a civil action on claim against debtor for 30 days after notice of expiration of automatic stay did not apply to extend time for mortgagee to record extension of its mortgage.).

But see In re Ivani, 308 B.R. 132, 52 Collier Bankr. Cas. 2d (MB) 206 (Bankr. E.D. N.Y. 2004) (state court had concurrent jurisdiction to decide whether state court contempt proceeding was subject to Bankruptcy Code's automatic stay provisions); In re Palmdale Hills Property, LLC, 423 B.R. 655, 63 Collier Bankr. Cas. 2d (MB) 937 (B.A.P. 9th Cir. 2009), aff'd, 654 F.3d 868, 55 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 57, 66 Collier Bankr. Cas. 2d (MB) 273, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) P 82046 (9th Cir. 2011) (Automatic stay arising in the bankruptcy court where a debtor files a petition for relief, that is, the “home bankruptcy court,” applies to action taken in any other bankruptcy courts); In re Midway Games, Inc., 428 B.R. 327 (Bankr. D. Del. 2010), opinion clarified, 2010 WL 2076955 (Bankr. D. Del. 2010) (Chapter 11 debtors stated valid claim to apply automatic stay to bar further investigation by Illinois Department of Labor (IDOL) and commencement of lawsuit by IDOL and debtors' former employees with respect to claims that debtors' officers unlawfully withheld paid time off wages owed to former employees pursuant to Illinois Wage Payment and Collection Act; debtors were real target of claims under Act, absence of insurance coverage meant that debtors would be forced to shoulder indemnity obligations to officers, thereby affecting debtors' remaining assets from court-approved sales, debtors would endure costs of statutory penalties associated with Act if judgment were entered against officers, and debtors' proposed payment of most former employees' claims made investigation and proposed litigation unnecessary.).

Section 362(a)(4) stays acts to create, perfect, or enforce liens against the property of the estate. See Bellini Imports, Ltd. v. Mason and Dixon Lines, Inc., 944 F.2d 199, 22 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 111, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) ¶ 74253 (4th Cir. 1991). The term lien is defined broadly under Code section 101, to include security interests, statutory liens, judicial liens, and even inchoate charges against property. See 11 U.S.C.A. § 101(37). Thus, creditors may not take a security or lien interest in property of the estate, or perfect any such interest, after a bankruptcy case has been commenced. See Mann v. Chase Manhattan Mortg. Corp., 316 F.3d 1, 40 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 189, 49 Collier Bankr. Cas. 2d (MB) 1715, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) ¶ 78787 (1st Cir. 2003) (mortgagee did not violate the automatic stay by continuing to record in the mortgagee's internal records accruing postpetition attorney's fees with respect to the secured claim without attempting to collect those charges or communicating the bookkeeping entries to the debtor or any third party); In re Gucci, 309 B.R. 679, 43 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 5 (S.D. N.Y. 2004) (registration of lien in estate property of Chapter 11 debtor in Rome, Italy was void ab initio); In re RW Meridian LLC, 553 B.R. 807, 810, 62 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 227 (Bankr. S.D. Cal. 2016) (post-petition sale of debtor's property was an action to enforce a tax lien and violated § 362(a)(4)); In re Heavey, 709 Fed. Appx. 101, 102 (2d Cir. 2018); In re Fine, 285 B.R. 700, 40 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 128 (Bankr. D. Minn. 2002) (there was no violation of the automatic stay by a mortgagee who, postpetition, effected a postponement of a previously scheduled foreclosure sale of the debtor's Property); CitiMortgage, Inc. v. Corte Madera Homeowners Ass'n, 962 F.3d 1103 (9th Cir. 2020) (remanding for a determination of when foreclosure-related notices were sent in possible violation of § 362(a)(4) or (a)(5)); In re Ohm, 2020 WL 4810066 (Bankr. N.D. Ohio 2020) (taking steps to renew lien did not violate the automatic stay because it was not creation, perfection, or enforcement of a lien). These proscriptions come subject, however, to a limited grace period for post-filing acts of perfection. Cf In re Canney, 284 F.3d 362, 39 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 57, 47 Collier Bankr. Cas. 2d (MB) 1508, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) ¶ 78610 (2d Cir. 2002) (under Vermont's strict foreclosure law, after the court has entered a foreclosure judgment, the mortgagor has an equity of redemption period, as fixed by the court, within which to redeem the property. Held, where the judgment was entered prepetition, the automatic stay did not apply so as to toll the running of the redemption period. Thus, the stay does not stop the running of time, and § 108(b) is the only applicable tolling provision in this context. After the redemption period expired, the stay did not prevent the taking of any further steps required by the state law (such as the filing of a certificate of nonredemption) to protect the foreclosing creditor's title against third parties)); see also In re APF Co., 274 B.R. 408 (Bankr. D. Del. 2001) (no violation of the stay unless there is an affirmative postpetition act that alters the status quo). Further, the Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals has held that a lien “is valid and enforceable” and its creation does not violate the automatic stay when it arises solely by operation of law and requires no post-petition “act” to create or perfect. See In re Garcia, 740 Fed. Appx. 163, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) P 83317 (10th Cir. 2018), cert. denied, 139 S. Ct. 2614, 204 L. Ed. 2d 264 (2019).

(CCH) P 80447 (3d Cir. 2006) (to avoid interfering with broad purposes served by automatic stay, arbitration panel had to halt prepetition arbitration proceeding arising out of insurance coverage dispute between liability insurer and insured-asbestos insulation installer as soon as scope of parties' submissions supported award that could diminish insured's Chapter 11 estate, and, by continuing beyond such point, arbitration proceeding violated automatic stay, such that both panel's deliberations and resulting award were void); In re WVF Acquisition, LLC, 420 B.R. 902, 52 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 131 (Bankr. S.D. Fla. 2009) (Actions of creditor in terminating the internet service that it provided to Chapter 11 debtor, a communication and information services company that itself provided internet access to customers in North America and Europe, and in attempting to strong-arm a general release from debtor as a condition to restoring service, were acts to obtain possession or control over property of the estate and acts to recover on a prepetition claim, and so violated the automatic stay); In re Three Strokes Ltd. Partnership, 397 B.R. 804, 50 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 272 (Bankr. N.D. Tex. 2008) (automatic stay applied to protect Chapter 11 debtor's interest, as junior lienholder, in real property on which senior lienholder was seeking to foreclose, so as to prevent senior lienholder from proceeding with nonjudicial foreclosure sale that would have extinguished debtor's interest in property, notwithstanding debtor's earlier execution of subordination agreement in senior lienholder's favor; execution of subordination agreement was not waiver of any lien rights that debtor had, and senior lienholder, by proceeding with foreclosure sale, was attempting to exercise control over property of Chapter 11 estate); In re Talsma, 468 B.R. 809 (Bankr. N.D. Tex. 2012) (accountant violated automatic stay by invoicing amount of its prepetition claim against debtors); In re BC Funding, LLC, 2014 WL 6764413 (Bankr. E.D. N.Y. 2014) (complaint filed against Chapter 7 debtor in corporate debtor's Chapter 11 case did not violate the automatic stay in his individual case because, to the extent that plaintiff sought to establish liability on a pre-petition claim, any such determination as to liability was merely ancillary to the claims allowance process).

On this subject, section 362 provides:

(k)(1) Except as provided in paragraph (2), an individual injured by any willful violation of a stay provided by this section shall recover actual damages, including costs and attorneys' fees, and, in appropriate circumstances, may recover punitive damages.

If such violation is based on an action taken by an entity in the good faith belief that subsection (h) applies to the debtor, the recovery under paragraph (1) of this subsection against such entity shall be limited to actual damages.

Section 362(b)(3) provides that “the filing of a petition … does not operate as a stay … of any act to perfect, or to maintain or continue the perfection of, an interest in property to the extent that the trustee's rights and powers are subject to such perfection under section 546(b) of this title or to the extent that such act is accomplished within the period provided under section 547(e)(2)(A) of this title.” 11 U.S.C.A. § 362(b)(3). Section 546(b), in turn, provides that “[t]he rights and powers of a trustee under sections 544, 545 [avoidance of prepetition statutory liens] and 549 [avoidance of postpetition transactions] of this title are subject to any generally applicable law that permits perfection of an interest in property to be effective against an entity that acquires rights in such property before the date of such perfection.” 11 U.S.C.A. 546(b)(A). Courts have interpreted section 546(b) to apply only to cases in which the “interest in property” is created prior to the bankruptcy filing, and its post-filing perfection relates back, as a matter of law, to the date of its creation. See Equibank, N.A. v. Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp., 884 F.2d 80, 85, 19 Bankr. Ct. Dec. (CRR) 1210, Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) ¶ 73095 (3d Cir. 1989) (exceptions to automatic stay provision which are created by section 546(b) apply only to interests in property created prior to the bankruptcy filing); In re Hernandez, 75 Collier Bankr. Cas. 2d (MB) 401, 2016 WL 1301642, *3 (Bankr. D. P.R. 2016) (“‘Interest in property’ referred to [section 546(b)] ‘must arise and exist pre-petition’”). Likewise, the legislative history of section 546(b) suggests that the “interest in property” must relate back to a period prior to the bankruptcy filing. See S. Rep. No. 95-989 (1978); H.R. Rep. Pa. 2011) (Unusual circumstances existed, warranting issuance of injunction, under section of Bankruptcy Code authorizing court to issue any order necessary or appropriate to carry out the provisions of Title 11, to restrain state-court proceedings against Chapter 11 debtor-limited liability company's sole members, who were non-debtors; members were involved in debtor's day-to-day restaurant operations, members were actively involved in debtor's attempts to secure postpetition financing, one member already had provided such funding to debtor, and debtor's ability to reorganize thus was clearly diminished without members' unfettered assistance.); In re Minh Vu Hoang, 2014 WL 4104193 (Bankr. D. Md. 2014), appeal dismissed, 2015 WL 2345588 (D. Md. 2015) (permanently enjoining a bankruptcy debtor from further litigation against the bankruptcy trustee and court-appointed professionals without leave of the bankruptcy court; debtor had made numerous frivolous and vexatious filings attempting to collaterally attack the court's determinations relating to property of the estate; furthermore, common-law Barton doctrine required leave of the court to bring an action against court-appointed officers).
